'Advertising' or 'advertizing' [http://triggs.djvu.org/century-
dictionary.com/djvu2jpgframes.php?volno=01&page=0088 The Century Dictionary
Online] [http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/advertize "advertize"
at Dictionary.com] [http://www.thefreedictionary.com/advertize
"advertize" at The Free Online Dictionary] is a form of communication for
marketing and used to encourage, persuade, or manipulate an audience (viewers,
readers or listeners; sometimes a specific group) to continue or take some new
action. Most commonly, the desired result is to drive consumer behavior with
respect to a commercial offering, although political and ideological advertising
is also common. This type of work belongs to a category called affective labor.

In Latin, ad vertere means "to turn toward." The purpose of advertising may also
be to reassure employees or shareholders that a company is viable or successful.
Advertising messages are usually paid for by sponsors and viewed via various
traditional media; including mass media such as newspaper, magazines, television
commercial, radio advertisement, outdoor advertising or direct mail; or new
media such as blogs, websites or text messages.

Commercial advertisers often seek to generate increased consumption of their
products or services through "branding," which involves associating a product
name or image with certain qualities in the minds of consumers. Non-commercial
advertisers who spend money to advertise items other than a consumer product or
service include political parties, interest groups, religious organizations and
governmental agencies. Nonprofit organizations may rely on free modes of
persuasion, such as a public service announcement (PSA).

Modern advertising was created with the innovative techniques introduced with
tobacco advertising in the 1920s, most significantly with the campaigns of
Edward Bernays, which is often considered the founder of modern, Madison Avenue
advertising.

In 2010, spending on advertising was estimated at $142.5 billion in the United
States and $467 billion worldwide 

Internationally, the largest ("big four") advertising conglomerates are
